title: Egypt Played Central Role in Israeli-Palestinian Cease-Fire
summary: Officials in Washington and Cairo had been in constant contact over the past week in an effort to stop the hostilities. Egypt played a critical role in brokering a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, a development that officials hope will lead to closer ties with the Biden administration, which up until now had been cool to Cairo over its human-rights record.

title: White House Trims Infrastructure Package to $1.7 Trillion; GOP Wants More Cuts
summary: White House lowers proposed spending on highways and broadband, and shifts some programs into other legislation. WASHINGTON-A slimmed-down White House proposal aimed at kick-starting bipartisan infrastructure negotiations fell flat with Senate Republicans, leaving fundamental questions no closer to resolution days before a Memorial Day target for progress in the faltering talks.

title: Georgia Judge Agrees to Unseal Fulton County Ballots in 2020 Election
summary: Decision paves way for audit of presidential election in state's most-populous county. A Georgia state judge ordered Fulton County, the state's most populous, to allow a voting group to inspect and scan absentee ballots cast there in the 2020 election.

title: Apple's Tim Cook Faces Pointed Questions From Judge
summary: CEO defends iPhone maker's commitment to users in countering claims by 'Fortnite' creator Epic Games. Apple Inc. Chief Executive Tim Cook faced tough questions from the federal judge who will decide whether the iPhone maker operates an improper monopoly, including about the competitiveness of its App Store payment system.

title: Gretchen Whitmer's Pipeline War
summary: Michigan's Governor assaults Canada and the Midwest economy.. The cyber attack on the Colonial Pipeline has led to surging gasoline prices on the East Coast. But that isn't stopping Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer from trying to shut down another crucial pipeline, no matter the harm across the Midwest and Canada.

title: Biden's Global Tax Trouble
summary: His corporate minimum tax rate is falling, as other countries rebel.. The Biden Administration's plan to use a new global tax regime as political and economic cover for its corporate-tax increases at home is already in trouble.

title: The Facts on Florida's Election Law
summary: Another state is accused of 'voter suppression,' despite its real record.. The fury at Florida's new voting law calls to mind the old one-liner about déjà vu all over again. Didn't we already do this outrage cycle in Georgia? One progressive group calls Florida's bill, signed recently by Gov. Ron DeSantis, a "sweeping voter suppression law." But the hot partisan sizzle doesn't come with any steak.

title: The Child Care Excuse for Unfilled Jobs
summary: A study finds parents have resumed work at the same rate as nonparents.. The government is paying people extra cash not to work, but the Biden Administration swears there must be another reason too few are working. Democrats claim that caring for children stuck at home is keeping parents from jobs. That's no doubt true in some cases, yet a new study suggests it's far less important than politicians claim.

title: White House Learned From the Past in Latest Israel-Hamas Conflict
summary: U.S.-Israeli ties were strained in earlier war in 2014, complicating peace initiatives. Biden administration officials made a conscious decision to avoid publicly clashing with Israel during the latest fighting in the Middle East, officials with knowledge of the discussions said, in part because they believed an antagonistic U.S. approach aggravated tensions during the last conflict, in 2014.

title: Bitcoin, Ether Fall After China Spurs Regulatory Fears
summary: Cryptocurrency prices extend selloff after China orders crackdown on mining, trading. Cryptocurrency prices dropped Friday, extending the week's selloff, after new comments from the Chinese government spurred fears of a regulatory clampdown in a country where most bitcoins are created.

title: Racism at Chicago's City Hall
summary: Mayor Lightfoot declines to do interviews with white reporters.. Ol' Jim Eastland must be smiling. The white segregationist Senator from Mississippi until 1978 has a surprising imitator in Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot, who said Wednesday she would not do one-on-one interviews with reporters who are white.

title: Does a Great Writer Have a Private Life After Death?
summary: Unsavory details of a poet's or novelist's story may cast light on his work. But they may not.. Pity the aging celebrity author. The day of reckoning looms. The vultures circle. They are unusually civilized vultures, but they will rip you to shreds anyway. They are literary biographers, of course, and they are apt to be merciless.

title: Biden Gets a Real Vaccine Job
summary: Instead of coasting along on Operation Warp Speed, he needs to vaccinate the world for global security.. By now you've heard that the Biden administration's attempt to waive drug company patents will make virtually no difference to poor countries fighting the Covid pandemic. Oddly, you've heard it from both supporters and opponents of his action.

title: S&P 500 Declines to End Turbulent Week
summary: Technology, other growth stocks relinquish early gains; bitcoin turns lower. The S&P 500 edged lower Friday in another volatile trading session as a continuing spring selloff knocked the broad index down for a second straight week.

title: Robotics Hub Carnegie Mellon Lands $150 Million Grant
summary: The Pittsburgh university looks to build next-generation technology and attract talent to region with long history of manufacturing innovation. Carnegie Mellon University will use half of a recently awarded $150 million grant to expand research and staff for its advanced manufacturing program and to build a new center focused on robotics innovation.

title: Home Prices Push to Record High, Slowing Pace of Purchases
summary: Cost for existing properties up 19% in April from year earlier; supply of homes remains limited. America's home-buying frenzy is cooling off for the first time since it heated up last year, as limited inventory and record high prices are excluding potential buyers.

title: Israel-Hamas Cease-Fire Holds Despite Jerusalem Clashes
summary: Resume Subscription. GAZA CITY-A cease-fire between Israel and militant group Hamas held on Friday despite clashes between Israeli police and Palestinians at a Jerusalem mosque that was the flashpoint for 11 days of fighting, with life slowly returning to normal.

title: Computers Speaking Icelandic Could Save the Language From 'Stafrænn Dauði' (That's Icelandic for 'Digital Death')
summary: To counter the dominance of English in technology and media, Iceland is teaching apps and devices to speak its native language. Telma Brigisdottir, a middle-school teacher in suburban Iceland, arrived at her classroom on a recent morning in March eager to introduce a new assignment. Dressed in a pink hoodie, she told her students: Turn on your iPad, log into the website Samromur, and read aloud the text that appears on screen. Do this sentence after sentence after sentence, she instructed, and something remarkable will happen. The computer will learn to reply in Icelandic. Eventually.

title: Not Every Quintile Pays Its Fair Share of Tax
summary: Rahm Emanuel is correct when he claims the Republicans have lost credibility on taxes but he perpetuates two tax myths of the left.. Rahm Emanuel is correct when he claims the Republicans have lost credibility on taxes ("Why the GOP has Gone Quiet Over Tax Hikes," op-ed, May 17), but he perpetuates two tax myths of the left. The first is the failure to distinguish statutory from actual tax rates. The Tax Cut and Jobs Act of 2017 lowered the top statutory tax rate from 39.6% (married filing jointly) to 37%, but by limiting the SALT (state and local tax) deductions to $10,000 sharply reduced the largest deduction for most wealthy taxpayers, effectively increasing the actual taxes paid. Democrats arguing to restore the SALT deductions are now seeking to cut taxes for the wealthy.

title: Hong Kong Freeze of Lai's Property Is Legal
summary: We will use all appropriate legal measures to crack down on activities endangering national security.. Regarding your editorial "Hong Kong Snatches Assets" (May 18): My decision to freeze certain property held by Jimmy Lai is neither "arbitrary" nor related to any person who "offends Beijing on political grounds."

title: Can the U.S. Lead a Human-Rights Alliance Against China?
summary: Resume Subscription. When Chinese leader Xi Jinping spoke with German Chancellor Angela Merkel last month, he didn't hide his irritation at the renewed bonds between Europe and the U.S. According to Beijing's readout of the call, Mr. Xi shared his "hopes that the EU will make the correct judgment independently and truly achieve strategic autonomy." By autonomy, of course, he meant a split with America.

title: Should California Forfeit Its Massive Covid-Aid Bonus?
summary: Doesn't California have to forfeit its share of federal funds?. Regarding your editorial "A Judicial Blow to Biden's Tax-Cut Ban" (May 18): As a result of California's substantial budget surplus, Gov. Gavin Newsom plans to provide middle-class families making up to $75,000 with a $600 rebate. Qualified families with dependents are eligible for an additional $500. Given that the $1.9 trillion Biden spending bill passed in March stipulates that states can't use their shares of the funds to "directly or indirectly offset a reduction" in "net tax revenue," doesn't California have to forfeit its share of federal funds? Surely, if Ohio can't cut taxes, California should not be allowed to provide rebates. The effect on net tax revenues is the same.

title: Popular Music Awards and Some Important Recounts
summary: I think "arty and pretentious" are poor word choices for Yes and the other progressive rock giants.. I think "arty and pretentious" are poor word choices for Yes and the other progressive rock giants ("Moving Targets: If We're Doing Vote Recounts, A Few Are Overdue," Review, May 15). Instead, try brilliant, innovative, amazing, extraordinary. Have you ever heard "Close to the Edge" (Prog Magazine's No. 1 rated LP of all time) or "Roundabout"-one of the greatest classic-rock songs of all time? I saw Yes live more than 30 times. Arguably, they are the best live performers with key members all music virtuosos in their own right.

summary: Tiny spiderlings have a unique and still-mysterious way of getting aloft that's inspiring to those of us who, like them, lack wings. Physicist Helen Czerski explores the complex science behind familiar phenomena. Read more columns here.

title: You'll Soon Be Able to Use Your Apple Watch Without Touching the Screen
summary: Companies like Apple and Spotify are making it easier for people with disabilities to use their products. Accessibility advocates hope more follow suit. Later this year, Apple Inc. will introduce features that allow users to control an iPad with their eyes, and its smartwatch with gestures like a pinch or a fist clench.

title: Tribune Says Alden Sale Approved Amid Confusion Over Key Shareholder's Vote
summary: Deal values media company at $635 million, makes Alden second-largest U.S. newspaper owner by circulation. Tribune Publishing Co. said Friday that its shareholders voted to approve a takeover offer from Alden Global Capital LLC, amid confusion over the vote of a key shareholder, in a deal that hands control of nine large daily newspapers to a hedge fund with a reputation for aggressive cost cutting.

title: U.S. Global Minimum Corporate Tax Proposal Gathers Momentum
summary: Germany and France join U.S. in supporting a minimum corporate tax rate of at least 15%. Germany and France welcomed the Biden administration's new acceptance of a minimum corporate tax rate as low as 15%, possibly smoothing the way to a global agreement as soon as July that could transform how international businesses are taxed.

title: Artists Inspired by Ghosts and Magic
summary: The new exhibition 'Supernatural America' features artworks full of occult symbols and paranormal experiences. Agatha Wojciechowsky was riding a New York City bus when, she claimed, she heard a voice. It was the early 1950s, and the former seamstress was learning to be a medium and spiritual healer. She had done many modest drawings, and when the bus stopped in front of an art-supply store, the voice told her, "Go in and buy some watercolors."

title: Confessions of a Career Government Bureaucrat
summary: Providing a good life for my family came at the cost of dedicating my career to mostly meaningless work.. At the beginning of my 32-year career as a government employee, I saw myself as an engineer first. I believed engineering, and by extension my role as a federal and county-level employee, was about listening, studying and solving problems. For years, I held on to that belief.

Davis, isn't the typical ivory-tower intellectual.

German publishing conglomerate Axel Springer SE is in talks to purchase digital-news outlet Axios, according to people familiar with the matter, a deal that would add to the company's U.S. holdings.

title: Netflix's 'High on the Hog' Centers Black Cooks in the Story of American Food
summary: From the origins of rice cultivation to contemporary haute cuisine, Black innovators have always been central to the story of American food. The Netflix series "High on the Hog: How African American Food Transformed America" seeks to change that.

summary: The columnist Washington feared; the age of artificial intelligence; an all-black musical that transfixed Broadway; interstellar adventure from the author of 'The Martian' and more..

title: Disappointment in Small-Town America as Buyers Lose Out on Properties
summary: Investors and bidders with deep pockets are snatching up homes in smaller cities and towns. Home prices in the U.S. have shot up in the past year, driven by limited supply, record-low interest rates and buyer demand. Bidding wars have spread from such high-profile locations as Palm Beach, Fla., and the suburbs outside New York City to smaller cities and towns, including long-neglected locales where properties typically sat on the market for months. The rise in prices is making it hard for first-time buyers to enter the housing market.

title: 'Black Fungus' Infects Thousands of India's Covid-19 Survivors
summary: Resume Subscription. NEW DELHI-A 52-year-old diabetic was recovering from Covid-19 at his home in the southern Indian city of Hyderabad in late April when his blood sugar levels shot up to four times the normal level. The left side of Yaseen Ahmed's face, including his eye, nose and gums started to swell, and there was some discharge.

summary: Aimed at the heart of the booming compact-crossover market, the CX-30 resembles the sporty Mazda Hatchback inside but lacks its fabulousness, finds Dan Neil. THIS ISN'T quite the Mazda I was hoping for, but it's close.

title: Getting More People Vaccinated Against Covid-19 Means Wasting Doses
summary: CDC says vaccinating people should take precedence over ensuring every dose in an open vial is used. When Covid-19 vaccines first arrived at health departments around the country, officials took to calling the shots liquid gold in a plea to prevent doses from going unused or being wasted.

summary: U.S. services businesses in early May saw their sharpest increase in activity in more than a decade. U.S. services businesses in early May saw their sharpest increase in activity in more than a decade, according to surveys of purchasing managers released Friday.

title: Ballrooms Become Courtrooms to Get Jury Trials Moving
summary: Resume Subscription. RANDOLPH, Mass.-When it was finally time to hold 12-person jury trials again in this Boston suburb after a yearlong pandemic hiatus, court officials knew their nearly 200-year-old courthouse's cramped rooms wouldn't work.

title: In Cease-Fire, Israel and Hamas See Gains-Toward Differing Goals
summary: As truce takes effect, the two sides each claim victory, but they don't have the same measures of success. TEL AVIV-Hamas wasted no time in proclaiming victory once a cease-fire with Israel took effect Friday, ending 11 days of fighting. Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, by contrast, was assailed by political foes and allies for what they characterized as a premature end to the campaign.

title: Boko Haram Leader, Responsible for Chibok Kidnappings, Dies
summary: Death of Abubakar Shekau removes one the world's most brutal and effective terrorists.

title: Delta Air Lines Taps GE Executive as Finance Chief
summary: Daniel Janki is set to become the airline's finance chief July 12. Delta Air Lines Inc. recruited a General Electric Co. executive to lead its finances following the departure of its longtime finance chief last year.

title: Why You Shouldn't Buy Bitcoin When You're Hungry
summary: Our decision-making is far less consistent than we think it is. Investors need to recognize that, and work to counter it.. You aren't an investor. You contain multitudes of investors.

title: 'The Columnist' Review: Master of the Merry-Go-Round
summary: The man behind every morning's must-read for the capital's movers and shakers: hated, admired, feared.. For almost 40 years, there was no more widely read, and perhaps no more widely hated, journalist in America than the ferociously independent syndicated columnist Drew Pearson. In a career that spanned every presidential administration from Hoover to Nixon, Pearson prowled the corridors of government, embarrassed the powerful, savaged the venal, fought secrecy, exposed blunders, and-not least-entertained and offended the public.

title: 'There Plant Eyes' Review: Blindness and Insight
summary: Coming in tales of blind prophets and inspiring stories of struggle, myths obscure the reality of sightless life.. A gospel soloist belted it outside a Brooklyn firehouse on the evening of September 11, 2001. President Obama crooned his own a cappella version after the shootings at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in 2015. And in my own childhood Baptist church "Amazing Grace," perhaps the most famous Christian hymn, was a touchstone: We'd sing it as a Sunday morning benediction, men on the first verse, women on the second, the pipe organ's tremolos on the third, and the entire congregation bringing it home, full-throated, on the fourth.

title: Will Fauci's Boss Answer the Questions about the Wuhan Lab?
summary: Lawmakers ask NIH Director Francis Collins about the potential origins of Covid-19.. Did Covid-19 originate in a Chinese laboratory funded in part by a grantee of Dr. Anthony Fauci's National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases? The world is waiting for an answer, and on Thursday several Republican members of the House and Senate asked Dr. Fauci's boss to help provide one. A related question is whether the deadly pandemic was the result of "gain-of-function" research, in which scientists genetically engineer deadly viruses which do not exist in nature in order to understand potential future threats.

title: Big Brains: New Books on Artificial Intelligence
summary: Machines driven by A.I. permeate our lives and may dominate the future. Should we be worried?. 'I, for one, welcome our new computer overlords," a wry Ken Jennings wrote in 2011 after he was decisively defeated in "Jeopardy!" by IBM's Watson computer and the artificial intelligence that powered it. A decade later, Mr. Jennings's sentiments seem prescient. Alexa and Siri inhabit our homes and our devices. Digital transformation has overtaken our workplaces. AI-driven recommendation engines help determine the movies we watch, the products we buy and the information we receive, influencing our preferences and inflaming our politics.

title: Cruise Lines Budget for Extra Costs as They Prepare to Restart Sailings
summary: The industry hopes to offer cruises out of the U.S. in July, which the CDC says is possible. Cruise lines are budgeting for extra costs as they prepare to resume voyages out of the U.S.-their main market-after a more than yearlong break because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Five Best: Books on the Soviet Home Front in World War II
summary: Selected by Wendy Z. Goldman, the co-author, most recently, of 'Fortress Dark and Stern.'. By Anika Walke (2015)

title: The Small Wonders of Robert Walser
summary: The author insisted that 'in trivialities lies the supernatural,' but his fiction was the product of deep attention to his art.. 'I saw something sweet, something mischievous, comical, capricious," we read in a 1913 essay titled "Dream Vision." "The seriousness of life rang like a bell into the licentious whispering and jingling and murmuring all around. The leaves whispered; the sweet, soft night wind blew; laughter resounded; tears flowed from eyes open wide; hearts trembled among all the magical impressions; music enframed and engulfed and engoldened the entirety. . . . As I saw what I saw I became a child, and the whole world, for as far as I could see, seemed reborn."

title: Science Fiction: Andy Weir's 'Project Hail Mary' Review
summary: Science saves the day, and maybe the world, in a novel from the author of 'The Martian.'. Andy Weir's "The Martian," published in 2011, was a classic example of minimalist sci-fi. Most of the novel's action centers on a single character, Mark Watney, an astronaut stranded alone on Mars. His quest to stay alive, using the tools and resources at his disposal, constitutes the central plot line. Not even the familiar sci-fi trope of unexpected Martian natives intrudes.

title: 'Footnotes' Review: Spotlight on 'Shuffle Along'
summary: When a pair of college friends with a knack for comedy met up with a musical double act, they had the ingredients for a sensation.. A musical comes together, finds its audience, flourishes and closes. With luck, it may be revived or reconceived in some way. More likely, the show is forgotten, recalled only by an odd lot of buffs and scholars. Despite its strengths, despite its popularity, it winds up being relegated to the footnotes of theater history.

title: Inside the Simon & Schuster Blowup Over Its Mike Pence Book Deal
summary: Resume Subscription. During an April workplace-culture session, one of many in the past year held by book publisher Simon & Schuster, topics included how to evaluate proposals from Black or LGBTQ+ authors and how best to promote them.

title: Mysteries: 'The Vanishing Point' Review
summary: Can a photographer's keen eye help find a runaway son?. Acclaimed photographer Rye Adler, one of the central characters in Elizabeth Brundage's "The Vanishing Point" (Little, Brown, 327 pages, $28), has been hailed as "the eye of a generation." Julian Ladd has been obsessed with Rye since the two met decades earlier in Philadelphia's Brodsky Workshop, "known among photography insiders as a breeding ground for the best talent." Julian, cowed by Rye's brilliance, gave up photography and made a lucrative career in advertising. But he still winces at the memory of Rye's public verdict on his own student efforts: "Your work has no soul." It felt, Julian perceives, like a "death sentence."

title: 'Six Square Metres' Review: Bounded and Bountiful
summary: The author makes a haven of growing things in a backyard less than half the size of a parking space.. If you're spatially challenged like I am, you scratch your head over figuring out "six square" of any measure. If you're American, the "Six Square Metres" of Margaret Simons's title may jam your circuits. And if you're any sort of gardener other than the most urban, contemplating a six-square-meter garden (once you've figured it out: I mentally lay myself side by side several times) evokes profound sympathies.

title: Poor Countries Ask Wealthy Ones to Do More to Stave Off Covid-19 Surge
summary: Developing nations pleading for vaccines say they are also short of oxygen, life-saving drugs and diagnostic tests. Public-health officials are pressing rich governments, including the U.S., to do more to help poor nations that are now at the center of the pandemic, as the devastating outbreak in India continues to exacerbate vaccine shortages in the developing world.

title: Children's Books: 'Is Was' Review
summary: Deborah Freedman's picture book captures moments of change.. Deborah Freedman captures a series of momentary transitions in the spacious, color-washed pages of "Is Was" (Atheneum, 32 pages, $17.99), a picture book that begins with an image of massing rainclouds. "This sky is the same sky that was blue, but now is spilling down," Ms. Freedman writes as, with the falling droplets, the reader's gaze is drawn down to the earth. We become privy to a chain of small events: a chipmunk and bird sip from puddles of rainwater until they're surprised by a fox. As the fox watches his fleeing prey, a bee bumbles past. Soon we're following the bee, now in exquisite watercolor detail, as it travels past an explosion of sunflowers. The movements of wild creatures crisscross throughout the book, from encounters with hunters (both winged and web-spinning) to eventual proximity to a human family. From moment to moment, what "is" becomes what "was" in this sublime meditation on constancy and mutability for children ages 3 to 8.

title: Airbus Engineer Championed Software Minders for Pilots
summary: Bernard Ziegler, who has died at age 88, moved computerized controls from military jets to commercial airliners. When Bernard Ziegler learned to fly in the 1950s, pilots controlled jets via cables and rods powered by hydraulics.

title: How to Brighten Dark Rooms Through Interior Design: Pro Ideas
summary: A restoration specialist gave new life to an old house weighed down by dark wood detailing-in this case, a 1912 Craftsman in Los Angeles-without destroying its charm. LAST YEAR, when Julia Kramer and Zachary Kaplan decamped from New York to Los Angeles for Ms. Kramer's new tech job, they set out to find an old house to make their first. The pair had grown to love the slightly cramped quirk of their Manhattan apartments and had no dreams of wide open spaces and slick stony countertops. But with two young sons and a collection of contemporary art (Mr. Kaplan is an executive at an arts nonprofit), they also wanted a house that would meet them in the now. Accommodating that agenda: A 1912 Craftsman in Koreatown that just needed some (gentle) brightening from local designer Jamie Haller, known for her conservative approach. "Restraint was the most important thing," she said.

title: Video Shows Louisiana Troopers Stun, Drag, Hit Black Man Who Died After Traffic Stop
summary: FBI, Justice Department's Civil Rights Division have opened criminal investigation into 2019 arrest and death of Black man. Louisiana state troopers are seen repeatedly using their stun guns before dragging a Black man and hitting him during a 2019 traffic stop after which he died, according to footage published this week by the Associated Press that it said was from a police body camera.

summary: Correspondence from a reader who's just crawled out of the earth. Hey everyone, I'm up, I'm out of the dirt, it's been 17 years, I'm chirping, I'm preparing to mate, I'm chirping again, I'm chirping some more, but I'm confused:

title: The Products You Need to Get Full, Gigi Hadid Eyebrows
summary: Pro tips for mastering the fluffy, gravity-defying arches that are beloved by models, TikTokers and Gen-Z-and can have an anti-aging effect on the rest of us. AURORA MAI wants her brows to "live their best lives." Once salons reopened, she was quick to schedule an eyebrow lamination-a chemical treatment akin to a perm that keeps brows perky and feathery for about 6 weeks. "I love having an uplifted, energetic look," said the 24-year-old CEO of the Visionary House, a San Francisco digital media agency. She also appreciates that the style is low-maintenance. Admittedly arch-obsessed, Ms. Mai once attempted soap brows, a TikTok craze that involves backcombing with a mix of bar soap and setting spray. The faddish technique delivered fleeting results, so she upgraded to longer-lasting lamination.

title: Elon Musk Wants to Make Teslas in Russia
summary: Tesla CEO says electric-vehicle maker is considering opening a factory in Russia. MOSCOW-Elon Musk raised the prospect of Russian-made Tesla Inc. cars, saying the company was considering opening a factory in the country as it looks to expand its production facilities globally.

title: China Hones Control Over Manganese, a Rising Star in Battery Metals
summary: Chinese firms join a cartel-like group to tighten output in key products, spurring prices and rival projects world-wide. China is tightening its grip on the global supply of processed manganese, rattling a range of companies world-wide that depend on the versatile metal-including the planet's biggest electric-vehicle makers.

title: How TikTok Cryptocurrency Influencers Are Teaching a New Generation of Investors
summary: An informal group of self-styled cryptocurrency advisors are using TikTok, Discord and other online platforms to instruct and, according to some, sometimes con nascent crypto investors.. On March 22, 2020, the day before the United Kingdom announced its first Covid-19 lockdown, Joel Davies joined TikTok, excited by the buzz surrounding it. He was unaware that doing so would lead him toward life-changing money. Davies, 23, had been interested in cryptocurrency since the age of 16, but apart from a small investment in Bitcoin, his curiosity remained on the back burner while he finished his studies in film, television and digital production at Bath Spa University. After graduating in 2019, Davies moved back into his parents' house in South Wales, stacked savings from his marketing job and, in the evenings, logged on to a Discord server, a communication platform he discovered through Dennis Liu, 26, a leading crypto influencer on TikTok, who also goes by the name VirtualBacon.

title: Hospitals Want More Time to Spend Covid-19 Relief Money
summary: Biden administration faces calls to extend June 30 deadline; providers say they need the funds to cover continuing pandemic care. Some lawmakers and healthcare providers are calling on the Biden administration to extend a deadline for hospitals to spend emergency coronavirus funding, with more than $30 billion remaining to be distributed out of about $187 billion Congress approved.

title: Remote Tipping Became More Popular During Covid-19
summary: The share of card transactions processed by Square that included a gratuity showed an increase. Americans are getting more signals that it is safe to visit bars and restaurants again. The reopening will test whether new tipping norms continue after evolving during the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Breeze Airways Launches as Travel Bounces Back, Competition Grows
summary: Latest venture from David Neeleman aims to fill in airline network gaps. JetBlue Airways Corp. founder David Neeleman is making another bet on the U.S. airline business as travel bounces back from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Concert Hall, Theater Aid Set to Be Distributed Next Week
summary: Performance-venues industry is frustrated as it waits for the Small Business Administration to award financial assistance. WASHINGTON-The Small Business Administration is aiming to start awarding Covid-19 aid to concert halls, theaters and other live-entertainment venues early next week, according to agency administrator Isabel Guzman.

title: Bitcoin Miners Are Giving New Life to Old Fossil-Fuel Power Plants
summary: The lofty prices of cryptocurrencies have investors sinking money into electricity generation, risking a backlash. Across America, older fossil-fuel power plants are shutting down in favor of renewable energy. But some are getting a new lease on life-to mine bitcoin. In upstate New York, an idled coal plant has been restarted, fueled by natural gas, to mine cryptocurrency. A once-struggling Montana coal plant is now scaling up to do the same.

title: Will Covid-19 Winners Now Lose, and Vice Versa?
summary: Businesses that benefited from the pandemic will lose some momentum and those that suffered will make up lost ground, but investors can't figure out how much. When it comes to the Covid-19 crisis, there are two kinds of companies: Those that benefited from it and have to worry how they will do as the crisis eases, and those that got hurt by it and have to worry if they will ever get their old business back.

title: A Beginner's Guide to Traveling in Alaska
summary: The 49th State is a hot ticket this summer, but it's not easy to plan a trip there. A brief guide for rookies, from high-flying adventures to low-stress sightseeing.. IF YOU NEED an antidote to Zoom culture, Alaska's the ticket, with its calving glaciers and opportunities for spelunking, witnessing wildlife (King salmon, bald eagles, jumbo moose) and dog sledding, even in June. And, for the energetic, summer's 22 hours or so of daylight double the fun. That said, only 5% of the state has roads: You'll need to wrangle assorted transport-planes, helicopters, trains and boats-and keep an eye on storms that might thwart the best-laid schedule. "It's quite a confusing place to plan a trip," said Marc Télio, whose luxury tour company, Entrée Destinations, does just that. Here, recommendations for a few different ways for first-timers to experience the 49th state, depending on just how adventurous they are.

title: DeepMind Tried-and Failed-to Win AI Autonomy From Google
summary: Alphabet cuts off yearslong push by founders of the artificial-intelligence company to secure more independence. LONDON-Senior managers at Google artificial-intelligence unit DeepMind have been negotiating for years with the parent company for more autonomy, seeking an independent legal structure for the sensitive research they do.

title: Food Supply Chains Stretched as Americans Return to Restaurants
summary: Shortages of key ingredients and labor are troubling suppliers as refrigerated transportation costs also surge. Americans are returning to restaurants, bars and other dining places as Covid-19 restrictions come down, adding new strains in food supply chains.

title: The Hidden Cost of Cheap Fashion Could Catch Up to Investors
summary: Shareholders are beginning to tune in to the environmental damage caused by throwaway fashion, even as consumers continue to shop. Cheap, disposable fashion is damaging the planet. If consumers don't seem to care, should investors?

title: True or False: Men Don't See the Mess
summary: Women report spending more time than men during the lockdown on cleaning, shopping and caring for children or adults. Single or married, childless or not, over time, across professions and even when they work longer hours and make more money, women spend more time cleaning house than men-and for some, the gap has widened during the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Seoul Proposes Vaccine Swap to Address Shortage
summary: Seoul wants to trade its future batch of vaccines for shots the U.S. can part with now in a one-for-one deal. SEOUL-South Korea has a wealthy-country solution to alleviate its delayed rollout of Covid-19 vaccines: propose a swap with the U.S., which has one of the world's biggest supplies.

title: SPACs Bolster the U.S.'s Global Lead in IPOs
summary: Europe is losing market share as firms bypass local exchanges to list in New York through blank-check company deals. The boom in blank-check companies earlier this year has lured companies to list in New York and has cut into Europe's share of the global market for initial public offerings.

title: Drought Imperils Economy in California's Farm Country
summary: Resume Subscription. DUNNIGAN, Calif.-Sitting in a pickup truck on his almond farm 100 miles north of San Francisco, Tom Butler pointed to a withered grove he has been planning to bulldoze in order to save his little remaining water for younger trees.

title: Higher Capital-Gains Taxes Could Snare Biden's Wealthy Cabinet Members
summary: Officials who have divested significant investments, or are in the process, include Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin. TOP BIDEN OFFICIALS COULD BE HIT with hefty capital-gains tax bills if President Biden's tax proposals become law, though they could defer the consequences until death under laws exempting people who sell assets to take on government jobs. According to financial filings, cabinet officials have unloaded millions in assets that would trigger capital-gains taxes of up to 23.8% under current law, and would be taxed up to 43.4% if Biden's plan passed unchanged.

title: To Cap Emissions by 2030, China Must Rein In Steel
summary: As steel tends to follow housing demand, Beijing has to find a better way to shift the economy away from housing and construction. China has committed to capping its carbon emissions by 2030, but its demand for steel-which happens to be the nation's top energy-consuming industry-remains ravenous. Meanwhile, steel prices have rocketed skyward in 2021, helping lift shares in companies like U.S.-based Nucor to new heights.

title: Israel-Hamas Cease-Fire Begins After 11 Days of Conflict
summary: Recent clashes have claimed the lives of more than 200 people. TEL AVIV-Israel and Palestinian militant group Hamas agreed to a cease-fire that began early Friday following pressure from the U.S. and its allies to end 11 days of fighting.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Liverpool and the Red Sox Won on His Watch. For Fans, That's Not Enough.
summary: Costly mistakes have made John Henry, the owner of both clubs, deeply unpopular despite World Series and Champions League titles. John W. Henry, co-owner of the Boston Red Sox and Liverpool Football Club, doesn't make many statements in public. For the shy former commodities trader, that is by design. So when he sat before the cameras not long ago, following the most controversial call of his tenure, fans knew it was significant.

title: Suit Accuses McDonald's of Racially Discriminatory Ad Spending
summary: Two companies owned by Byron Allen allege burger giant's ad spending disproportionately shortchanges Black-owned media outlets. Two companies owned by media mogul Byron Allen have filed a lawsuit against McDonald's Corp. , accusing the fast-food giant of discriminating against Black-owned media companies.
